captions.text:
We take navigation for granted these days
- GPS receivers guide airplanes, cars, and
even cell phones!

But did you know that the Global Positioning
System is basically a big clock in space?

There are thirty GPS satellites in orbit,
and they just broadcast where they are and
what time it is.

All your phone GPS has to do is receive signals
from four satellites and it can triangulate

its location in the four dimensions in which
we live – three space and one time.

But actually it's not that simple! In order
for navigation to work, the satellites carry

atomic clocks accurate to the nanosecond – otherwise
your GPS receiver might tell you you're halfway
across town when you're still in the driveway.

And special relativity tells us that moving
clocks run slow, while general relativity

tells us that clocks run faster higher in
a gravitational field. These effects don't

quite cancel – general relativity wins out
and time indeed runs faster up in orbit with
the satellites!

But some of the engineers working on the first
GPS satellite couldn't bring themselves to

believe that their clock would actually run
fast just from being higher up, so they sent

it up uncorrected! Within minutes it was off
by enough to impair GPS navigation, and by

the end of the day, GPS receivers would have
been wrong by tens of kilometers! Needless

to say, the engineers turned the correction
back on, and these days they trust general
relativity!

Oh, and one last thing - GPS is also a nuclear
weapons detector: there are always at least

four GPS satellites visible from any point
on earth, and because of this, any nuclear

detonation will be seen by enough satellites
to pinpoint exactly where and when it took
place.

comments.author: Rubikorigami

comments.text:
.....You were taught....wrong. Since General Relativity states the faster 
you go, the more time slows down, and if the satellites were not carrying 
their own clocks, they'd constantly be giving erroneous signals. Plus your 
average GPS satellite costs 100-150 million, and adding a few atomic clocks 
costing 10-25K is nothing.

Don't believe me? then here
http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/~pogge/Ast162/Unit5/gps.html
http://www.physics.org/article-questions.asp?id=55
comments.author: Lazurkri

comments.text:
Great video, thanks!
But I have one question: the orbits of all the GPS satellites are of the 
same altitude and speed. Thus, the relativity effects on them (42 
microseconds/day, if I'm not mistaken) should be the same. On the other 
hand, that's not the local time on the satellite that a GPS receiver uses 
(a *receiver* has no onboard atomic clock!), it's a difference between two 
such times. And here the relativity effects, being the same for two 
different satellites, should cancel each out.
Then why did not the system work even without the GR corrections?﻿

comments.author: JeramieH

comments.text:
+sam witwicky
 Just to clarify, the phones on the plane aren't relevant. G.P.S. devices 
are designed to locate G.P.S. satellites, not the other way around. It 
sounds kinda backwards, but that's why it's impossible for your phone to 
calculate it's location if it only has access to three or fewer satellites.

Just like sailors used the stars, our devices use the satellites for 
navigation by looking up at them, taking measurements and recognizing 
patterns. And also like the stars, the satellites don't have to be looking 
back at us for G.P.S. to work. They don't even know we're watching.

Source:
http://www.gps.gov/support/faq/#findmyphone

comments.text:
What if instead of having clocks on the satellites, you had a ground-based 
atomic clock transmit the time to the satellites? That way, the satellites 
would always know what time it was on the ground. Wouldn't that make things 
simpler? There would be no need to correct for the effects of relativity 
and you would need only a single clock.﻿
comments.author: Nathan Warford

comments.text: +Shinzon23 Good Conclusion sir.
comments.author: Swapnil Netankar

comments.text:
because smarter people than you or I thought about it and came to the 
conclusion that having the clocks in orbit would be less a pain in the ass 
to keep calibrated. Plus, it provides redundancy; if that ground clock goes 
down for whatever reason, then the GPS constellation wouldn't all suddenly 
start giving off erroneous signals and killing people due to incorrect 
navigation

comments.author: Philandros

comments.text: +Narcissist86 Great explanation.
comments.author: Morefire Z

comments.text:
+Vir Animus " It requires four satellites to determine a position in three 
spatial dimensions. "Space" is more formally termed "Space-Time" because 
there are actually four dimensions; Three spatial dimensions and a time 
dimension, and to oversimplify the process, you require one satellite per 
dimension to accurately trilaterate an object that moves."

Not really... It always takes n + 1 satellites for n number of SPATIAL 
dimensions. It has nothing to do with time, or the fact that points could 
be moving. It all has to do with geometry.

Take a straight line for example - that represents 1 spatial dimension. If 
you use only one satellite, how would a measurement go? Well, the satellite 
sends a signal, and your receiver receives the signal one second lighter. 
All the information you have now is that you are 1 light-second away from 
the satellite - but which direction? It could be left, or right of it on 
this line. That's why you need 2 satellites - to cross out one possibility 
and narrow down your location. Notice how nothing is mentioned regarding if 
the receiver is in motion, or whether it can move, or whatever. It is not 
relevant.

When it comes down to it, it's because for n given spatial dimensions, 
multilateriation involves solving for a system of equations with n+1 
unknowns. Now you can argue that because the measurement done by the 
satellites and receivers is time based, that's how time is involved... But 
judging by your queries involving immobile objects and such, that's not 
really your train of thought.
comments.author: Narcissist86

comments.text:
+Philandros Henry is correct; It requires four satellites to determine a 
position in three spatial dimensions. "Space" is more formally termed 
"Space-Time" because there are actually four dimensions; Three spatial 
dimensions and a time dimension, and to oversimplify the process, you 
require one satellite per dimension to accurately trilaterate an object 
that moves.

"You're not thinking 4th dimensionally" ~Doctor Emmit Brown

I actually pose another question, perhaps Henry can shed light. If what 
I've described is true, would that only mean that 4 satellites are required 
for an object which changes position with respect to time? If an object 
such a building with a fixed position relative to the surface of the earth 
were in fact immobile relative to the surface of the earth, could three 
satellites be used to locate that object?

I would intuit that the fourth time dimension is necessary because the 
objects we track with GPS are either moving, or capable of moving. I 
imagine that without a fourth satellite for time, data from the other 
satellites may disagree on time and prevent an accurate or coherent 
calculation on an object moving through space relative to the earth.

Is this thought making any sense?

comments.author: Moments

comments.text:
+Dramatic Moments
Here:
http://www.nbi.ku.dk/english/www/spinoff/spinoff/gps/

".. Therefore, the GPS receiver has to be in contact with at least three 
satellites. Then it gets a crossing point, which shows its own position.."

Under the section "How GPS works". I think the source 'ought' to be 
reliable, given it's owned and worked by the university of copenhagen

But that it takes four referencepoints and not three, to find a point in 3d 
space, is right. Now that you're saying it, and after I've given it some 
thought, I can see the truth of it. And that has lead me to wonder.. Both 
on how it can then be, that it takes three sattelites to find the crossing 
point (as they describe it). but also how he in the video says it requires 
4 sattelites (given that he considers the space to be 4d - making it 
require 5 referencepoints).

I don't know.. but I'm thinking, that if they take three sattelites, they 
should be able to somewhat determine the true crossingpoint, knowing that 
earth is somewhat round in shape. Cause two spheres will make a circle of 
crossingpoints and using a third sphere, will create two crossingpoints 
with the before found circle of crossing points. This would then make two 
possible positions. But as the earth is somewhat round in shape, we should 
be able to make approximations of which positions could be true (knowing 
the center and avg. radius to the surface). So in other words, we could 
just consider earth to be our fourth sphere, though it isn't. If doing so, 
one of the crossing points position could be determined a possible 
position, and one wouldn't. But that would be a flawed approach for sure.. 
and that also raises the question, why not just use four sattelites for a 
better approach.

So I don't know, perhaps it really does take four sattelites, or perhaps 
there's a better solution to doing this, using only three sattelites.
comments.author: Philandros

and he might not referenced as it something he picked up over the years, 
general knowledge
comments.author: Moments

comments.text: +Philandros can i have a reference to what you said please?
comments.author: Moments

comments.text:
+Dramatic Moments
The referencelist is for the viewers and readers, not for the writer. I 
think referencelists should be considered mandatory, for youtubers making 
educational videos.. Some claims are questionable, and in those cases it 
would be nice to be able to review their sources.

As an example:
The claim that 4 sattelites are needed, was a claim that I would have liked 
to review. Cause from what I've heard and read, it only takes three 
sattelites and that also seem intuitively true. A user recieves three 
signals, from three sattelites. Given the time it took for the reciever to 
recieve the signals, the distance between reciever and sattelite can easily 
be calculated as t*c. Now knowing the distance, you can create circles, 
from the point of the sattelite, with the radius being the distance. 
Creating three of these, you can triangulate the reciever, in our three 
dimensional space. But then there's special and general relativity, saying 
that our measured times are different, so we got to take that into account. 
By knowing the relative velocity between our inertial frames, the one we're 
in and the one the sattelite is in (orbiting earth), we could account for 
the time dialation casued by the special relativity (t' = lorentz 
factor*t). With the distance between the earth and the sattelite, we could 
also account for general relativity - or at least as far as I know, cause 
I'll admit to not really knowing much about general relativity. But 
anyways, if these former mentioned are true, we should be able to 'convert' 
our time into their time (the GPS's time). And so, I do not see a reason 
for the need of a fourth GPS and that creates an uncertainty of the 
validation of the information (at least I get uncertain)..

But it's just a general thing, that I don't understand why they don't fix 
It. Cause it doesn't seem like much extra work.. And I feel fairly certain 
that they do spent some time on researching before making these videos, and 
that in itself should provide them with sources..

comments.text:
If time runs faster in higher orbit someone on the space station would age 
faster than someone on earth. This is a general relativity time dilation, 
so it really has nothing to do with the twin "paradox", which is more of a 
special relativity thing. We don't notice a big difference in the ages of 
astronauts because the effect is still fairly small, its just big enough to 
throw off GPSs because of how precise they have to be.

comments.text:
The usual crap. GPS does not need relativity. This does not mean that GPS 
is not sensitive to relativity effects. But in reality the clock 
corrections are determined empirically by constant monitoring, regardless 
of their cause, and corresponding corrections are sent up to the 
satellites. That's how it works. Only in hindsight you may interpret the 
corrections by relativity theory, but the numbers don't match because there 
are one-hundred other effects which also have to be corrected.

comments.text:
trilateration is the process of determining absolute or relative locations 
of points by measurement of distances, using the geometry of circles, 
spheres or triangles. In addition to its interest as a geometric problem, 
trilateration does have practical applications in surveying and navigation, 
including global positioning systems (GPS). In contrast to triangulation it 
does not involve the measurement of angles. en.wikipedia.or 
g/wiki/Trilateration

comments.author: ASBusinessMagnet

comments.text:
Doubters in 1977:

"At the time of launch of the first NTS-2 satellite (June 1977), [...] 
there were some who doubted that relativistic effects were real. A 
frequency synthesizer was built into the satellite clock system so that 
after launch, if in fact the rate of the clock in its final orbit was that 
predicted by GR, then the synthesizer could be turned on ..."

- http://www.leapsecond.com/history/Ashby-Relativity.htm

Bonus link: track the GPS satellites currently over your horizon at 
http://www.n2yo.com/?s=35752|32711|32260|27704|26407|25030|22700|22108|22014|21552 
(via Andrew Holme's GPS project page)

video by +Henry Reich via +Kam-Yung Soh﻿

comments.author: Ed S

comments.text:
Nice. And in 1977, Eddington's experimental proof of GR was already 58 
years old. There's a very watchable dramatisation of Einstein's development 
of GR and Eddington's experimental proof, set against the backdrop of the 
first world war: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0995036/

But I guess there will always be morons: guys who think the Earth is 6000 
years old, guys who think climate change is a hoax, guys who look at Chris 
Hadfield's cover of Space Oddity and mumble about wasted tax dollars...

comments.author: spamerman

comments.text:
1. nowadays light (EM) is the way we send and receive information, so it 
actually goes as fast as light. 2. the whole "it takes time to get here" 
doesn't account for any form of time dilation. if it were a matter of 
distance than the clocks would run late, not slow. 3. the time dilation 
experienced by satellites is caused by (this is the simple version) a 
difference in the experienced gravities in the surface of the Earth and up 
in orbit:(Fg=-Gm1m2/r^2)
comments.author: Montecation

comments.text:
And why the "time" runs slower, because information can not move faster 
than the speed of light. It takes time... movement.. to get from the place 
x to the place y. The clocks run the same speed, but to look at the clock 
far away the information is out of date because of the speed limit.

comments.author: J Parril

comments.text:
So how can you pinpoint a nuclear detonation using GPS? All these 
satellites do is report their location in time, the only way you could 
pinpoint the detonation location would be to have a GPS at that location, 
and it would be destroyed instantaneously.
comments.author: danpascooch

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure that when he talks about time running faster at higher 
altitudes, it actually means that "time" itself is affected by the strength 
of a gravitational field, not just a clocks ability to measure that passage 
of time accurately.

comments.author: Valexonline

comments.text:
My guess would be something like, the higher up you go, the less magnetic 
field your electronic clock is exposed to. this Mag Field presents a force 
of electrical resistance that is greater the closer you get to the earth's 
core, so they run a bit more efficiently at high altitudes. Could get the 
same general effect with mechanical clocks if you consider air pressure 
providing resistance on the gear movement. (I reserve the right to be 100% 
wrong as this is 100% guess)
